context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: Pac-12 commissioner Larry Scott to push NBA to change one-and-done rule
context_meta.summary: Pac-12 commissioner Larry Scott told reporters Sunday that he would like to see the NBA change its one-and-done rule and require prospects who choose to play college basketball to remain in college for at least three years. "There are certain things about the youth basketball culture and the influence of shoe companies and agents and runners that's not going away," Scott said, according to The San Francisco Chronicle. In November, the Pac-12 created a task force to examine "systemic issues threatening college athletics" in the wake of an ongoing federal investigation into bribery and fraud in college basketball. Scott, who oversees the task force, said he will discuss the group's preliminary findings with the Pac-12 board of directors this week and release it to the public next month.

context_meta.title: Michael Beasley Could Be Removed from Knicks Starting Lineup, Rips Teammates
context_meta.summary: New York Knicks head coach Jeff Hornacek told reporters Saturday it's "possible" he will remove power forward Michael Beasley from the starting lineup because of an ankle injury and his lackluster defensive play in the aftermath of a 128-105 loss to the Los Angeles Clippers on Friday, according to the New York Post's Marc Berman.  Beasley has provided steady scoring to the tune of 12.5 points per game on 49.4 percent shooting from the field and 40.7 percent from three during his first season with the Knicks, but his defense has noticeably lagged behind.  According to NBA.com's lineup data, the Knicks are allowing 110.5 points per 100 possessions with Beasley on the floor compared to 105.6 when

Though Beasley made a big shot down the stretch during the Knicks' comeback from a 19-point deficit, it was still another dud for the enigmatic forward. Beasley finished with six points on 3-of-9 shooting and committed five turnovers. Hornacek said Saturday after the Knicks' debacle in Los Angeles he may make a move and indicated the slumping Beasley's ankle was hurting. context_meta.author: ipostwhaticareabout
context_meta.title: Rolling with the punches: Bobby Portis and Nikola Mirotic are both having career-best seasons
context_meta.summary: The upward trajectories of Bobby Portis' and Nikola Mirotic's seasons may be one of the most amazing storylines in yet another wacky NBA season filled with them. Think about it: After playing well all season as a reserve, including alongside a player he punched in the face to break two facial bones, Portis becomes a starter on Monday. Portis overcame an eight-game suspension for that punch of Mirotic to post career-high statistics virtually across the board. Meanwhile, Mirotic, who missed 23 games after Portis' aforementioned punch, has helped lead his second team to a seven-game winning streak. When he did so with the Bulls in December, it marked the first time in NBA history a team followed

context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: Lakers finding meaning in season's final stretch as wins keep coming
context_meta.summary: This year did not mark the first time a mid-season trade deposited Isaiah Thomas into the early stages of a long-term rebuild. Since arriving from Cleveland on Feb. 8, Thomas has on multiple occasions likened the Lakers' situation to that of the 2015 Boston Celtics, who were 11 games under .500 before acquiring Thomas and went on to win 40 games and earn the eighth seed in the Eastern Conference. “It was a young team thinking rebuild and play the young guys and things like that,” Thomas said, “but we came together and was like, shoot, if we play hard and leave it all out there on the floor, anything can happen. After sweeping a four-game trip and extending their winning streak to a season-best five games, something is clearly afoot for the Lakers (28-34), who with 20 games remaining already have more wins than in any of the previous four seasons.

context_meta.author: DeltaBravo
context_meta.title: Isaiah Thomas Praises Lonzo Ball's 'Poise' After Lakers' Win Vs. Spurs
context_meta.summary: Don't look now, but Lonzo Ball has played some outstanding basketball of late. The Los Angeles Lakers point guard had an abysmal start to his rookie season, shooting a lowly 24 percent from 3-point land in November. But Ball has been brilliant since returning from a knee injury that sidelined him for 15 games before the NBA All-Star break. In the four games since returning from the knee sprain, Ball is shooting 63.3 percent from long distance and is averaging 12 points, 7.2 assists and 6.7 rebounds per game. He has shot 59.4 percent from downtown in his last nine games. Ball continued his torrid stretch Saturday night, hitting six treys in the Lakers' come-from-behind 116-112 win over the San

context_meta.summary: The Portland Trail Blazers and Los Angeles Lakers are playing their best basketball of the season heading into their game Monday night at Staples Center. The Trail Blazers have won a season-high six in a row and the Lakers a season-best five straight. Portland has won 14 consecutive games overall against Los Angeles, tied for its second-longest winning streak against the Lakers in franchise history.

context_meta.summary: Bulls big man Bobby Portis will get his opportunity to start Monday against the Celtics. But Denzel Valentine will finally get his chance to shine. With all the talk out of practice the last few days about Portis taking his instant energy from the bench to the starting lineup, one very important question had to be answered Sunday: Who picks up the slack? Portis was averaging almost 17 points per game off the bench since the start of February, and it isn't like the coaching staff is counting on Cristiano Felicio to pick up that scoring with the second unit. That's where Valentine comes in. Like Portis, Valentine is a first-round draft pick (14th overall in 2016) looking to make a lasting impression

context_meta.summary: While 20 games remain on the schedule, the 2017-18 NBA season can be deemed a success for the Los Angeles Lakers. They've transformed from the worst defensive team in the league to a top-15 unit this season. "We have to be able to maintain a certain level throughout the course of the game and stay at that level and be more consistent during the whole 48 minutes." context_meta.summary: The Warriors wanted to come back from the NBA's All-Star break playing some of their best basketball of the season, and four games into the “second half” of the campaign, it seems as if the Warriors are doing just that. Golden State is now 4-0 since the All-Stat break after beating the John Wallless Washington Wizards 109-101 Wednesday night in the nation's capital. Kevin Durant led the way with 32 points on 60 percent shooting, and the Warriors saw solid performances from Klay Thompson (despite a poor start shooting), Draymond Green, and Andre Iguodala. Golden State will play the Hawks in Atlanta on Friday. They'll then have the weekend and Monday off before playing the Nets on Tuesday in Oakland.

context_meta.summary: ATLANTA — Golden State will assign rookie forward Jordan Bell to the G League for the Santa Cruz Warriors' game Sunday evening against the Memphis Hustle. Bell, 23, is still rounding back into form after missing 14 games with a swollen left ankle. In the three games since his return, he has totaled five points, six rebounds and five assists in 28 minutes. With Golden State not playing again until Tuesday night's game against Brooklyn, Bell can play with Santa Cruz on Sunday and return for Golden State's practice Monday. Golden State is taking Saturday and Sunday off. Bell is averaging five points, 3.8 rebounds and one block per game this season.

context_meta.title: CEO of gunmaker that produced Florida shooter's weapon: 'I share nation's grief'
context_meta.summary: American Outdoor Brands’ profit fell sharply over the three months ending 31 January, it reported. James Debney, the British-born chief executive of the company that made the rifle used by the gunman in the school shooting in Florida last month, on Thursday said he “shared the nation’s grief” over the massacre. Announcing American Outdoor Brands’ (AOB) latest results, Debney called the shooting, which killed 17 at the Marjory Stoneman Douglas high school in Parkland, an “incomprehensible loss of life” but said the company would continue to support the right of Americans to carry firearms.

context_meta.title: Kevin Smith Considers a Vegan Diet After Heart Attack – Here Are Some Heart-Healthy Tips
context_meta.summary: After suffering a serious heart attack, director Kevin Smith has said that he is seriously thinking about his diet, and considering going vegan for his health. In an Instagram post, Smith opened up about his health crisis. “Doctor who saved my life at the #glendale hospital told me I had 100% blockage of my LAD artery (also known as “the Widow-Maker” because when it goes, you're a goner). If I hadn't canceled the second show to go to the hospital, the Doc said I would've died tonight,” wrote Smith. “This is all a part of my mythology now,” added the filmmaker, “and I'm sure I'll be facing some lifestyle changes (maybe it's time to go Vegan).” Kevin Smith / Instagram A plant-based diet can be

context_meta.author: ipostwhaticareabout
context_meta.title: Isaiah Thomas, Lakers shred Heat to continue late-season surge
context_meta.summary: MIAMI (AP) — Julius Randle got the Los Angeles Lakers started. Isaiah Thomas finished the job. And there is playoff talk in Lakerland. Thomas scored a season-high 29 points, Randle added 25 and the Lakers continued their improbable surge by shredding the Miami defense on the way to a 131-113 win over the Heat on Thursday night. The Lakers are still six games back of the No. 8 spot in the West — but Thomas wants them to think big. "I want this team to think we're going to win," Thomas said. "We have the talent to win. We have the players in this locker room to win and the only thing we should be thinking about is trying to take that next step — and that's get to the playoffs." They keep playing

context_meta.author: rocky.j.mountain
context_meta.title: Lonzo Ball, Kyle Kuzma, Josh Hart bring Lakers Troll Wars to dinner
context_meta.summary: So much for finding peace at the dinner table. Los Angeles Lakers rookies Lonzo Ball, Kyle Kuzma and Josh Hart went out to eat in Miami on Wednesday night, and brought the Troll Wars with them. Each of the three newbies took to Instagram to clown a teammate or two. Zo flamed Kuz for ordering milk and cookies like Santa Claus. Kuzma fired back at Ball for eating “plain cheese” and took aim at Hart for being unable to play “Fortnite” with a cast on his left hand. Hart gave it right back to Kuzma for his “Ed Hardy” jacket, and recommended that his followers find someone like Lonzo to help them just as the point guard sliced up his steak for him. context_meta.author: DeltaBravo
context_meta.title: Derrick Rose's NBA Future Is Officially in Jeopardy
context_meta.summary: When video surfaced last week appearing to show Derrick Rose shooting by himself in an empty gym at Cleveland State University, the common reaction was one of sadness. With Thursday's deadline for free agents to be playoff eligible, the phone has yet to ring with anything approaching a significant offer, multiple league sources told Bleacher Report. "The injuries and lack of enthusiasm to play hurts him," a Western Conference executive told B/R. The first part is true; there's no doubt that Rose's injury history transformed a superlative talent seemingly destined to be a max player for life into a role player who agreed to a one-year deal for the veteran's minimum of $2.1 million to be a backup on LeBron James' Cavaliers.
